column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0108] While copper has better electronic conductivity than steel, it can present fabrication issues.
#Text=For example, attaching a current collecting copper disk to the copper sheet may require specific laser welding settings and the appropriate jigs to provide continuous pressure during the weld.
#Text=[0109] As such, the electrical attachment of the collector disk with the negative electrode requires specific manufacturing techniques.

#Text=In an example embodiment, the copper collector is perforated and attached at multiple points along the negative electrode so that the electrode is attached to the current collector at multiple points along its length.
#Text=By activating a greater area, the charge efficiency is further enhanced.
#Text=The perforations also serve to locate the electrode and allow electrolyte to penetrate the stack uniformly during the electrolyte fill operation.
#Text=In another embodiment, the collector disk is slotted to achieve the named advantages.
#Text=In another embodiment, the copper collector disk requires only center hole for the electrolyte to enter.
#Text=The structure of the rest of the disk is then determined by the requirements of the method of attachment (i.e. unperforated, perforated or slotted as required).
#Text=In another embodiment, the copper collector disk is covered with tin or a tin alloy and attached to the current collectors by soldering.
#Text=In a preferred embodiment, the current collectors are bent as described above with reference to FIG. 4a to improve attachment of the collector disk to the current collectors.

#Text=[0110] One disadvantage associated with the welding of current collector disks to the active-material-supporting conductor (current collectors) is that the heat input can damage thin heat sensitive separator membranes.
#Text=This can promote short circuits and significantly curtail service life.
#Text=A non-welded pressure contact can mitigate this problem.
#Text=In certain embodiments, two circular copper disks are connected together with a bent strip of copper.
#Text=The upper disk is resistance welded to the cap of the cylindrical cell (e.g., a sub-C cell) and the lower disk is pressurized to make electrical contact to the jellyroll.

#Text=[0111] When the cap (and vent assembly) is mated to the cell body during cell assembly the electrical contact to the jellyroll is maintained by the pressure created by a "spring" that has been inserted between the two parallel copper disks.
#Text=The spring may be a steel spring that has been plated with copper, tin, or another protective metal that has high hydrogen overpotential.
#Text=Alternatively the spring may be substituted for with a pressurized rubber annulus or "o" ring that is resistant to the alkaline media.
#Text=Such materials may be EPDM (Ethylene Propylene Diene Monomer) or Vitons (fluoroelastomer family from DuPont Dow Elastomers, L.L.C.).
#Text=In either case sufficient pressure is maintained such that low impedance electrical resistance is maintained between the cap and jellyroll.
#Text=In certain embodiments, the pressure exerted by the o-ring presses downward through or from a crimp in the cell can.
#Text=In some cases, it is desirable to provide a reinforced bottom of the can.

#Text=[0112] While this method is particularly useful for the negative electrode contact where there is minimal oxidation of the metal parts and minimal oxidation of organic-based rubber compounds it may nevertheless also be applied to the positive electrode.
#Text=In such cases, the contact surface may be two interconnected nickel disks that are pressurized by a similar spring arrangement.
#Text=However, there may be some degradation over time associated with the formation of resistive nickel oxides on the nickel contact area.
#Text=In order to prevent the progressive build up of resistance the disks may be electroplated with cobalt.
#Text=Although still subject to oxidation the cobalt oxides provide much better conductivity than nickel oxides.
